computer.colors: Palette: 16.7 millionOn screen: 256 in normal modes, 262144 in HAM-8
computer.coprocessor: AGA based chipset: 8374 Alice (memory controller and blitter), 4203 Lisa (video control chip), 8364 Paula (sound & I/O), Gayle (I/O, IDE interface), 391425 Budgie (bus controller)
computer.description:
In October 1992 the Amiga 1200 was launched. This machine took the A500 approach to computing with the "distinct" Commodore case, but including the AGA chipset present in the A4000, 2 MB RAM, and the PCMCIA slot from the A600.
At the price of £399 it sold like hot cakes and is seen as one of the best Amigas to date. It appears to have been rushed to launch for the Christmas period with manuals claiming to give you the opportunity to upgrade from 1mb to 2mb chip ram with FPU. It is, however, a darn fine machine that can be easily upgraded for most of your needs.
After Escom bought the Amiga during 1995 it was relaunched to mass outrage. The machine still cost £399, £150 more than it had done a year previously and was not enhanced in any dramatic fashion. It was released in two versions- the Amiga Magic pack and the Amiga Surfer bundle. Unfortunately, the former was never released due to Escoms financial situation. The Escom Amigas were also struck by incompatibility problems due to a different disk drive being used, it was actually a PC high-density drive mechanism that had been altered to allow compatibility with the Amiga file system. Unfortunately, some games that hit the hardware directly would not run. A circuit upgrade was released free of charge that allowed users to fix the drive problem.
Source: Amiga Interactive Guide _______________________

item.description: GVP Accelerator card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;GVP ACCELERATOR CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This card is connected to the internal expansion connector of the Amiga 1200. It features:<br><br> - A Motorola 50 Mhz 68030 microprocessor<br> - Up to 16 MB of additional RAM<br> - An internal clock with battery back-up<br> - A fast SCSI port <

Viper Accelerator card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;VIPER ACCELERATOR CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Steve Green</b> who sent us this photo says:<br><font color="#666666"> The Viper card is an 68030 expansion card. This particular model was a 28mhz 68030 with FPU. Also added was a 16 MB dimm (which I bought from the states for 115 dollars in early 96!). Together these quadrupled the speed of a standard A1200. You could also get a 50 mhz 030 card, but this was one of the earliest.</font><

MIDI Gold 500 |||by Golden Hawk Technology|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MIDI GOLD 500 </strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;by Golden Hawk Technology</strong><br><blockquote>This is a MIDI interface for the Amiga 500, 2000, or 3000... <br><br> It features :<br> - one MIDI In<br> - two MIDI Out<br> - one switchable Out/Thru<br> - one MIDI/Serial Switch<br> - one Out/Thru Switch<br><
Memory expansion board||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MEMORY EXPANSION BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>2 / 4 / 6 / 8 MB expansion card here fitted with 2 MB.<

Video board||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;VIDEO BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This board featured 2 MB of RAM and allowed the Amiga to be connected to a standard VGA monitor. All the video modes could be displayed, including the interlace one.<

Hard Disk card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;HARD DISK CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>40 MB SCSI card from SUPRA CORP.<br><br> Additional SCSI devices could be connected in chain trough the back connector<

computer.name: Amiga 1200
computer.ports: RS-232 serial port, Centronics parallel port, external disk interface, 150 pin local expansion port, Clockport, 2x RCA audio, PCMCIA/JEIDA card interface, IDE hard drive interface, composite video out, RF out, 2x Atari joystick/mouse ports
computer.ram: 2 MB Chip RAM, expandable to 10 MB max (2 MB Chip RAM + 8 MB Fast Ram)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Expansions trap door<br> <b>(2)</b> Mouse or Joystick-1 DB9 connector <br> <b>(3)</b> Joystick-2 DB9 connector<br> <b>(4)</b> External disk drive DB23 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Serial DB25 connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Parallel DB 25 connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Stereo sound output RCA plugs <br> <b>(8)</b> RGB video output DB23 connector<br> <b>(9)</b> Composite video output RCA plug<br> <b>(10)</b> RF/TV modulator output<br> <b>(11)</b> External power supply unit plug <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INSIDE A1200</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> A metallic shield prevents magnetic field from being emitted by the computer <br> <b>(2)</b> 170 MB 2.5" hard disk drive <br> <b>(3)</b> 512 KB ROM chips holding Kickstart 3.0<br> <b>(4)</b> 68030 accelerator card<br> <b>(5)</b> 3.5" internal floppy disc drive <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MOTHERBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk connector area.<br> All the passive components are miniaturized versions<br> The Sony chip is a video RGB encoder<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;LAPTOP PROTOTYPE</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the numerous attempts in designing a portable version of the Amiga system. Same design was applied to the Amiga 600 version.<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;3.5" HDD</strong></font><br><blockquote>3 1/2" drives did also fit into an A1200 case.<br> <b>Steve Green</b> who sent us this photo specifies:<br><font color="#666666"> The harddrive is a 3 1/2" 1.6 GB Samsung drive. It is attached to the main board via a 3 1/2 inch vide cable connected to a 2 1/2 inch ide cable via a convertor.</font><

computer.size: 9.5" deep × 18.5" wide × 3" high / 8 lbs25cm deep x 49cm wide x 7cm high / 3.1 Kg
